summary.text: Torque measures rotational effect of force: τ = r⊥F. Perpendicular distance r⊥ from axis to force line determines turning effect.

importance.text: Torque determines whether objects rotate. Equal and opposite torques create rotational equilibrium in structures and machines.

explanations.text: Force alone doesn't cause rotation. The distance from rotation axis matters—longer lever arms amplify rotational effect.
Angular momentum conservation requires torque for angular acceleration. τ = dL/dt where L is angular momentum.
Rotational inertia resists angular acceleration. Torque overcomes this resistance, analogous to force overcoming mass inertia.

questions.text: True or False: Torque is maximum when force acts perpendicular to the lever arm.

modelAnswer.text: True. Torque τ = rF sin θ reaches maximum when sin θ = 1, which occurs at θ = 90° (perpendicular). When force is parallel to lever arm (θ = 0°), sin θ = 0 and torque is zero. The perpendicular component of force creates the rotational effect, so maximum torque occurs when the entire force is perpendicular to the radius vector.

questions.text: True or False: For complete equilibrium, both net force and net torque must be zero.

modelAnswer.text: True. Complete static equilibrium requires both translational equilibrium (ΣF = 0) and rotational equilibrium (Στ = 0). Net force = 0 prevents linear acceleration, while net torque = 0 prevents angular acceleration. Both conditions are necessary - an object could have balanced forces but still rotate if torques don't balance, or have balanced torques but still accelerate linearly if forces don't balance.

questions.text: True or False: The lever arm is always the physical distance from pivot to force application point.

modelAnswer.text: False. The lever arm (moment arm) is the perpendicular distance from the axis of rotation to the line of action of the force, not necessarily the physical distance. If force is applied at an angle, the effective lever arm is r⊥ = r sin θ, which is shorter than the physical distance r. Only when force is applied perpendicular to the physical arm does the lever arm equal the physical distance.

questions.text: True or False: Torque direction depends only on force direction, not on the position where force is applied.

modelAnswer.text: False. Torque direction depends on both force direction and position. The same force applied at different positions can create different rotational directions. Torque follows the right-hand rule: curl fingers from radius vector to force vector, thumb points in torque direction. Both the force vector and position vector (from axis to application point) determine the resulting torque direction through their cross product.

summary.text: Static equilibrium requires both ΣF = 0 (no linear acceleration) and Στ = 0 (no angular acceleration). Both conditions must be satisfied simultaneously.

importance.text: Determines stability of structures, machines, and biological systems. Engineers use these principles to design safe buildings, bridges, and mechanisms.

explanations.text: Objects need both translational and rotational stability. Balanced forces prevent sliding; balanced torques prevent tipping or rotating.
Newton's laws extend to rotation. ΣF = ma becomes ΣF = 0 for a = 0. Similarly, Στ = Iα becomes Στ = 0 for α = 0.
Conservation laws demand it. Linear momentum conservation requires ΣF = 0. Angular momentum conservation requires Στ = 0.

questions.text: True or False: A system in equilibrium is always stable.

modelAnswer.text: False. Equilibrium exists in stable, unstable, and neutral forms. A pencil balanced on its tip satisfies ΣF = 0 and Στ = 0 but is unstable - any small disturbance causes it to fall. Stable equilibrium requires that small displacements create restoring forces/torques that return the system to equilibrium. Unstable equilibrium creates forces/torques that drive the system further from equilibrium when displaced.

questions.text: True or False: Any force can be replaced by an equivalent force-couple system acting at any other point.

modelAnswer.text: True. A force F acting at point A can be replaced by the same force F acting at point B plus a couple with moment M = F × d, where d is the distance from A to B. This maintains both the translational effect (same net force) and rotational effect (same net moment about any point). This principle is fundamental in statics for relocating forces to convenient points for analysis.

questions.text: True or False: A pin support can provide moment reactions.

modelAnswer.text: False. A pin (hinged) support allows rotation and therefore cannot provide moment reactions. Pin supports can only provide force reactions in x and y directions. Only fixed supports can provide moment reactions because they prevent rotation. This is why simply supported beams (pinned at both ends) cannot resist moments, while cantilever beams (fixed at one end) can resist moments at the fixed support.

questions.text: True or False: An object will always balance if supported at its center of mass.

modelAnswer.text: True. When an object is supported at its center of mass (center of gravity), the weight force acts through the support point, creating zero torque about the support. This automatically satisfies rotational equilibrium (Στ = 0) regardless of the object's orientation. The support force balances the weight, satisfying translational equilibrium (ΣF = 0). This is why objects balance at their center of mass.
